examples.text: He was charged with possessing a shotgun without a licence.
I'm afraid this is the only suitcase I possess.
The gallery possesses a number of the artist's early works.
Belgium was the first European country to possess a fully fledged rail network.

definitions.definition: to have a particular quality or feature

examples.text: I'm afraid he doesn't possess a sense of humour.
workers who possess the requisite skills for the task
He credited her with a maturity she did not possess.
Isaak 's songwriting possesses a timeless quality.
Young adults possess incredible purchasing power.

definitions.definition: to have a powerful effect on somebody and control the way that they think, behave, etc.

examples.text: I was possessed by a desire to tell her everything.

definitions.definition: to make somebody do something that seems strange or unreasonable

examples.text: What possessed him to say such a thing?

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French possesser, from Latin possess- ‘occupied, held’, from the verb possidere, from potis ‘able, capable’ + sedere ‘sit’.
